snippet.textDisplay: You know i really think Dark Souls 3 has one of the most beautiful graphics in any games i played to date, and i find DS1 and DS2 Graphics really lacking compared to DS3, especially DS2 and the hit sounds and  blunt feel. I really expected that DS1 remaster will basically bring DS1 game and lore into DS3 graphics, which would have been heaven... that... that was not the case at all. It really feels like a very lazy polish, like when a modder "fixes" GTA5 and its just a buncha reshading and stuff. Especially why i like this video because the red line comparison even shows you that its barely any improvment. I really feel like they missed the mark on the Remaster hard. Like look at Dead Space. For its time, very good on release, but doesnt hold up as much today. But the Dead Space REMASTER?!?!!? MY FUCKING GOD. Absolutely Gorgeous, fluent, and so much improvments. Even some changes to the game which improve it a ton in my opinion, but simply gorgeous re-creation of a many years old game with new graphics and capabilities. That kind of a remake is what i expected DS1 rmk to be, and i gotta say i was let down very hard upon playing the first 1/3 of it. I really feel like FrSoft could go the NaughtyDog route here and do a DS1 RE-REMASTER, and basically bring it up to DS3 standards. Same with DS2

snippet.textDisplay:
-Bloom was greatly diminished. I think this was a bad decision. Not only did this take away some of the mysterious look of the game but it also made metallic objects way less reflective.

-Blacks were intensified. This is usually desired to make things look less washed out, but loweing blacks can sometimes give you a stylistic approach akin to something that was printed like an old book with illustrations or manga. To me the game used to look like medieval fantasy artwork from the 80s and the remaster wrongly thought this was something to be fixed.

-The lighting effects of items on the ground, sorceries, miracles, pyromancies and special attacks were enhanced, but sometimes at a cost. Ground items now look less eerie and ethereal and more like a round blue light. The colors of these effects were also strenghtened, similarly to how they did with the blacks, which changed the intended style of the game. This can also be seen in ambient torches.

-Framerate was greatly improved. This is nice.

-Higher resolutions supported. This is nice.

-Quality of life things like holding down your down button to go back to your first item; being able to use password based connections; use more than one soul at a time, and being able to change the hud size are probably the only fundamentally good things about the remaster, especially the password based connectivity.

-The bonfire to vamos is a substantial change to the game's design which I frowned upon at first, but I ultimately agree with it because the road to vamos can be very annoying if you upgrade fire based weapons. In fact they could have even added another for each blacksmith just like the original has one for Andre.

-Blacks were intensified. This is usually desired to make things look less washed out, but loweing blacks can sometimes give you a stylistic approach akin to something that was printed like an old book with illustrations or manga. To me the game used to look like medieval fantasy artwork from the 80s and the remaster wrongly thought this was something to be fixed.

-The lighting effects of items on the ground, sorceries, miracles, pyromancies and special attacks were enhanced, but sometimes at a cost. Ground items now look less eerie and ethereal and more like a round blue light. The colors of these effects were also strenghtened, similarly to how they did with the blacks, which changed the intended style of the game. This can also be seen in ambient torches.

-Framerate was greatly improved. This is nice.

-Higher resolutions supported. This is nice.

-Quality of life things like holding down your down button to go back to your first item; being able to use password based connections; use more than one soul at a time, and being able to change the hud size are probably the only fundamentally good things about the remaster, especially the password based connectivity.

-The bonfire to vamos is a substantial change to the game's design which I frowned upon at first, but I ultimately agree with it because the road to vamos can be very annoying if you upgrade fire based weapons. In fact they could have even added another for each blacksmith just like the original has one for Andre.

snippet.textDisplay: People have to keep in mind, or at least from my point of view. That the primary things that make this game a remaster isn‚Äôt the graphics, but the mechanics. Faster estus drinking, multiple soul consumption, framerate fixes, but most of all MULTIPLAYER. Maybe it won‚Äôt take me 40 minutes, and dozens of failed summons before I can get my friend in my game. I loved dark souls, but never got to play it with my friends nearly as much as 2 and 3 because of this. Just the little things like this is what makes me want it. Appreciate the little things.

snippet.textDisplay:
I understand the complaining, but if you don't play on PC, there are undeniable improvements: From 720p -> 1080p. From 30 fps -> 60 fps, with no drops during bosses/blighttown/whatever. Light-effects improved. 6 players at the same time online, hopefully with less lag/connection issues (mostly because people themselves have better connectionse). DLC included, that makes the remaster worth for whoever didn't have it on console.
I mean, it is still a sloppy job, and many things could have been done (improved HUD, no chain-lag backstabs allowed for instance), but it has some value.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
The textures, lighting, particle effects, and general bug fixes are very welcome improvements. 

But when I first saw the trailer, I was hyped for a full-on remaster with the same art styles and levels of detail as Bloodborne and Dark Souls 3. 

I mainly blame Halo CEA and MCC for setting the bar *SOOOOO HIGH* when it comes to modern remasters. But hey, who am I to complain. DS Remastered is still a pretty decent improvement for what it's worth.
snippet.textOriginal:
The textures, lighting, particle effects, and general bug fixes are very welcome improvements. 

But when I first saw the trailer, I was hyped for a full-on remaster with the same art styles and levels of detail as Bloodborne and Dark Souls 3.

snippet.textDisplay:
Things people fail to notice:

- Fromsoftware has nothing to do with this remaster. So don't expect major changes. 

- This game is meant for people who own current-gen consoles who missed out on this game.

- The remaster looks better, while keeping the original feel of the game. It has new effects, realistic lighting, higher resolution, 60fps and better performance.

-Also, this is a remaster, not a remake!

snippet.textDisplay:
I will continue with the PC version with DSFix and mods, for now. I do not care about online interaction (actually I'd rather play alone). I intend to buy the remastered version when and if there are good mods release for it as well. The original version has a problem loading high-resolution textures that prevent very heavy mods. Let's wait and see what the remastered version will look like. I foresee the true remastered version being released by modders.
The bloom effect is very much lacking. It gave a rather fanciful appearance to the whole ominous place.
I think for anyone who only played on the consoles of the last generation, it's a good request to replay in high resolution and 60FPS. Just like for anyone who has never played DS but prefers consoles.

Now the game have working shadows, now clothes don't reflect light sources like steel does, more detail variety. AA works, better fire, 4K cutscenes with much less fog, OMG THEY FIXED BLIGHTTOWN FPS!
Oh, better PvP and some good old Jolly Coop. 

People saying "it's the same" or "moneygrab" probably are watching from their smartphones at low resulution. Don't mind them.
